subject: Re: [junit] a test framework to codify levelizaton?

messageBody:
On Sun, 18 Jul 2004, Timothy Wall wrote:

> That's wonderful. But it's impossible and likely incorrect to compare
> those results to any other project in any way other than a purely
> statistical analysis over many, many projects. There are far too many
> other variables involved when running the tests.

Well, as just another people of anecdotal evidence, for both of the
largish (more than 1000 unit tests) projects I've worked on in the last
litte while, we also had all of the unit tests running in 20-30 seconds.
(The functional tests took much longer, unsurprisingly--our total test
runtime goal was about 10 minutes, which we achieved a most of the
time.)

Our basic development strategy was this:

1. During development, run just the specific test suite on the
code we were working on. (This took a few seconds.)

2. Before commit, run all unit tests. (This took 20-30 seconds.)

3. Before commit, decide which, if any, functional tests are likely
to be important to run, and run those. (This took 0-3 minutes.)

4. Before commit, if really worried, or the changes are widespread,
or whatever, do a full test run. (10 minutes)

We'd ocassionally get checkins, especially by the junior developers,
that broke stuff that they hadn't run the test for, but it was not that
common an occurance, and it was caught pretty quickly, since pretty much
everybody was doing a few full test runs per day, anyway. It was a habit
to do an update and kick off a full test run before lunch or a coffee
break.

So we were already using an informal level system, as you can see.
Whether it's worth the bother of formalizing this, I don't know; I
consider it an important part of developer training to learn how to do
analysis of what tests should be run, which means that I would prefer
that all developers are doing this themselves on a continuous basis,
even at the expense of having to deal with the ocassional mistake.
That's the price of learning, after all.
